definition: not to enjoy popular support/to be unpopular
to obtain/to get/to gain/to catch (a disease)/proper/suitable/proud/contented/to allow/to permit/ready/finished
structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc
to have to/must/ought to/to need to

sentences.english: Chang is said to be unpopular and at odds with some top generals.
sentences.chinese: 据说，张成泽不得人心，而且与多名高官不和。

sentences.english: He went on to say that the practice to control others is against the will of the international community.
sentences.chinese: 钱其琛指出，在国际上控制别人的做法是不得人心的。
他是一个不得人心的国王。

sentences.english: She was so unpopular that on one could be found to put in a word for her.
sentences.chinese: 她太不得人心了，没有一个人肯替她说情。

sentences.english: He will have to make tough decisions about an unpopular war.
sentences.chinese: 他必须对一场不得人心的战争作出艰难抉择。

sentences.english: The impression that Mr. Potts regarded his colleagues as inferiors made him unpopular.
sentences.chinese: 波茨先生总是把同事当作下级，这点使他不得人心。

sentences.english: John is smart and knows the business backwards, but people don't believe in him.
sentences.chinese: 约翰头脑灵活，谙熟业务，可就是不得人心。

sentences.english: The first political casualty at the federal level was the unpopular home minister.
sentences.chinese: 联邦层级的第一个政治牺牲品是不得人心的内政部长。

sentences.english: Lose public support this matter, if stem of good, call a song Gao with few.
sentences.chinese: 不得人心这事，如果干的好，叫曲高和寡。

sentences.english: Prejudice and lies are untenable and the Cold War mentality has no popular support.
sentences.chinese: 他表示，偏见和谎言站不住脚，冷战思维不得人心。

sentences.english: The high price of food and water is making governments more disliked.
sentences.chinese: 高价的食物和饮用水使得政府更加不得人心。

sentences.english: The legislature repealed the unpopular Rent Act.
sentences.chinese: 立法机关废除了不得人心的租借法案。

sentences.english: Those who are unjust in their manner of doing things lose the support of the people.
sentences.chinese: 办事不公的人不得人心。

definition: to go against the tide (idiom); to do things all wrong/to try to turn back history/a perverse way of doing things
lit. to go to war without just cause (idiom)/to act without justification
breaking faith and abandoning right (idiom); to betray/treachery/perfidy
that which is yearned for by the public
ambition of wild wolves (idiom); rapacious designs
to change sides in a war/turncoat
an unjust cause finds little support (idiom, from Mencius)/cf 得道多助[de2 dao4 duo1 zhu4] a just cause attracts much support
